awd_titl_txt: ATD:   Collaborative Research:   Efficient sampling for real-time detection and isolation of threats in networks
awd_abstract_narration:
While modern technologies generate multiple, interconnected sources of data, which can be observed in nearly real time, physical constraints and budget limitations require efficient sampling of these data streams. Incorporating such constraints in the design of threat detection systems has the potential to lead to significant savings in resources. The goal of this project is to develop fundamental statistical theory and methods for the efficient, real-time sampling of networks, and the subsequent detection, identification and prevention of threats of different nature, such as terrorist activities and credit fraud. The developed methodologies will be tested on real-world data, where the underlying community structure in times of crisis will be discovered using cell-phone call records. The theoretical knowledge that will be gained in this project will be incorporated into the material of graduate-level courses that cover adaptive experimental design and sequential detection. Two graduate students will contribute significantly in this research. The project will make every effort to include qualified students of underrepresented groups in these research activities.

This research will address two fundamental research questions: 1) how to detect and identify, in real time, anomalous clusters in network data subject to sampling constraints, and 2) how to efficiently allocate limited resources in order to delay or prevent the realization of threats from the identified anomalous clusters. The mathematical formulation of these questions leads to novel problems in network-based, adaptive experimental design and sequential detection, whose solutions require the creative combination of tools from various fields, such as statistical inference, sequential analysis, and information theory. The theory and methods developed in this work will guide the development of threat detection algorithms and will be tested in concrete applications, such as social networks in times of crisis that will be discovered based on cell-phone call data. Overall, this is a multidisciplinary proposal, spanning social sciences, statistics, and engineering, whose goal is to obtain an arsenal of efficient network sampling schemes and novel threat detection algorithms, grounded on a strong theoretical background.

por.por_cntn:
In many engineering, technological, scientific areas, data are collected over multiple streams, which are generated by distinct sources and are monitored in real time. It is often critical to identify as quickly as possible those data streams, if any, that are, in a certain sense, “anomalous”, or represent some kind of “signal”. However, the practical considerations and constraints for this task can vary greatly. Indeed, in certain setups it may be possible to combine data from different streams; in others, decisions may have to be based only on local data. It may sometimes be beneficial, or even necessary, to sample only a subset of data sources, not all of them, at each time period. Finally, in some cases it may be possible to allow for only a small number of possible decision times.

 

We have proposed and analyzed novel methodologies for simultaneously testing multiple hypotheses using sequentially acquired data, which address each of the above practical constraints and considerations. For each of them, we have developed a general asymptotic optimality theory, which provides rigorous, theoretical support for the proposed testing schemes, as well as guidance for their design and implementation. In each of them, we have explicitly incorporated the possibility of prior information on the true subset of signals, typically on its size, and evaluated its potential benefits. Moreover, we have demonstrated the advantages of the proposed schemes against competing ones in the literature both theoretically and in numerical studies.

 

Another main contribution has been the development of a general theory and methodology for sequential multiple testing that do not rely on the assumption of statistically independent data streams, thus, they are applicable to a significantly larger range of problems. We have studied in detail the detection and identification of a dependence structure in an unknown subset of data sources. In this setup, we have incorporated more versatile prior information, e.g., of topological nature, on the unknown true subset of anomalous data streams. We have also removed the assumption of independence in the problem of sequential change detection under sampling constraints, where we have considered the problem of quickly and accurately detecting the emergence of such a dependence structure. 

 

The above statistical methods are applicable to a wide range of applications, whose key features are the sequential monitoring of data source and the need for accurate, real-time decisions. We have considered, in more detail, the application of the above methods to the real-time detection and identification of social-media accounts that are utilized by influence operations and misinformation campaigns. We have also used these techniques for understanding the most informative features of the media contents for differentiating such accounts. 

 

The above results have been disseminated through journal and conference publications, conference presentations and invited talks, as well as graduate-level courses taught by the PI. Four graduate students at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign worked on the above problems, were trained in the areas of sequential multiple testing, sequential change detection, and adaptive design, developed novel methodologies, established deep theoretical results, and presented this research to several workshops and conferences.
